revision.text:
{{Infobox Organization |name = Instituto Antártico Argentino |image = Direccion Nacional del Antartico.gif |size = |caption = IAA emblem |abbreviation = IAA |formation = 1962 |status = [[Government of Argentina|Government Organisation]] |purpose = |headquarters = |location = |region_served = {{flagicon|Argentina}} [[Argentina]] |membership = |leader_title = |leader_name = |leader_title2 = |leader_name2 = |main_organ = |parent_organisation = |affiliations = |num_staff = |budget = |website = {{URL|http://www.dna.gov.ar}} }} [[File:Antártida Argentina.png|right|thumb|270px|Argentina claims sector between meridians 25° West and 74° West]] [[File:Argentine Antarctica bases map.jpg|thumb|270px|Argentine research bases (red: year-round, green: summer only)]]
The '''Instituto Antártico Argentino''' ('''IAA'''; {{lang-en|Argentine Antarctic Institute}} ) is the [[Argentine]] federal agency in charge of orientating, controlling, addressing and performing scientific and technical research and studies in the [[Antarctica|Antarctic]].<ref>[http://www.dna.gov.ar/INGLES/INDEX.HTM official site] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110303004340/http://www.dna.gov.ar/INGLES/INDEX.HTM |date=2011-03-03 }}</ref>
Known as [[Argentine Antarctica]] ({{lang-es|Antártida Argentina}}) the country claimed a sector as part of its [[national territory]] consisting of the [[Antarctic Peninsula]] and a triangular section extending to the [[South Pole]], is delimited by the [[25th meridian west|25° West]] and [[74th meridian west|74° West]] meridians and the [[60th parallel south|60° South]] parallel.<ref>{{cite book| last = Beck| first = Peter J. | title = The international politics of Antarctica | publisher = Routledge| year = 1986 | page = 119 | url = https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=-4g9AAAAIAAJ&oi=fnd&pg=PP15&dq=Argentina+Antarctica&ots=N6GIahpMCV&sig=oJRWi_sB41tY7bK54xgpjYEmRTg#v=onepage&q=Argentina%20Antarctica&f=false | isbn =0709932391}}</ref> Administratively, Argentine Antarctica is a [[Departments of Argentina|department]] of the [[Provinces of Argentina|province]] of [[Tierra del Fuego Province (Argentina)|Tierra del Fuego, Antarctica, and South Atlantic Islands]].
This sector overlaps with [[Antártica Chilena Province|Chilean]] and [[British Antarctic Territory|British]] claims but, under the [[Antarctic Treaty System]], there are no attempts by Argentina or any other country to actually enforce territorial claims in Antarctica.
==Mission== According to the principles of its creation, the Instituto Antártico Argentino participates with its scientific, technical and administrative staff, in a wide range of national and international programmes for a better understanding of the Antarctic. Scientists are trained and deployed on [[Argentine_Antarctica#Argentine_bases|Argentine bases]] for researching on different fields of science, including [[Atmosphere]], [[Biology]], [[Oceanography]], [[Weather]], [[Chemistry]], [[Ozone Layer]], [[Global warming]] and [[Carbon dioxide|CO2]].
==History==
===Exploration prior to the IAA=== [[Image:Sobral and Nordenskjöld.jpeg|thumb|right|Sobral with Nordenskjöld, circa 1903.]] [[File:Unimog Antartico de la Fuerza Aerea Argentina.jpg|thumb|right|[[Unimog]] vehicle]]
[[José María Sobral]], who is considered in Argentina the father of the [[Argentine Antarctica]] and a national hero, began exploration at the end of 1901. In 1903, the [[Argentine Navy]] corvette [[ARA Uruguay|ARA ''Uruguay'']] commanded by'' Captain de Corbeta'' (Lieutenant commander) [[Julián Irízar]] successfully rescued the [[Sweden|Swedish]] expedition team of [[Otto Nordenskjöld]]. In 1904 the Argentine permanent presence in Antarctica began with the opening of [[Orcadas Base]] on [[Laurie Island]]. Argentina was the only nation to have an Antarctic base for 40 years until the British built a base on the same islands.
On April 1, 1940, the first radio communication by [[radio ham]]s was made between [[Orcadas Base]] (LSX) and [[Buenos Aires]] (LU 7 ET).
On February 7, 1942, an amphibious [[Boeing-Stearman Model 75|Stearman]] aircraft embarked on the [[ARA 1 de Mayo|ARA ''1 de Mayo'']] cargo ship made the first Argentine flight over Antarctica.
On December 13, 1947 an [[Argentine Naval Aviation]] [[Douglas DC-4]] piloted by [[Commodore (rank)|''Comodoro'']] [[Gregorio Portillo]] flew over the [[Antarctic Circle]] in a 15 hours and 30 minutes flight.
===IAA=== On 17 April 1951, [[Hernán Pujato]] founds the ''Instituto Antartico Argentino'', by Decree Nº 7338.
In 1953 the [[San Martín Base]] started operations, and [[Jubany]] base opened two years later.
In 1958 the United States handed over the [[Ellsworth Station]] located in the [[Weddell Sea]].
In 1965 the [[Military of Argentina|Argentine military]] conducted a land military manoeuvre known as [[Operación 90]] in order to reach the [[South Pole]].
In the winter of 1968 at the request by the British embassy in [[Buenos Aires]], an Argentine Navy [[Douglas DC-4]] successfully delivered medical supplies to the British base EFE where one of its members, James K. Portwirie, was through a medical emergency. However, after a few days, Portwirie's situation worsened, making a rescue necessary. An [[Argentine Air Force]] aircraft attempted to reach the base but crashed without casualties. On August 9, in the middle of the Antarctic winter, the [[Argentine Navy]] [[icebreaker]] [[ARA General San Martín (Q-4)|ARA ''General San Martín'']] was sent to rescue Portwirie. The operation was successful, gaining the thanks of the [[British Antarctic Survey]]: ‘‘an internal campaign like this was never attempted before in Antarctic History‘‘.<ref>[http://www.histarmar.com.ar/Armada%20Argentina/Buques1900a1970/BPolares/BPRompSMartin.htm ''. Sir Vivian Fuchs, el vencedor del Polo Sur, dijo: "Ruego acepte nuestras sinceras gracias por el rescate del enfermo de nuestra estación en islas argentinas. Una campaña invernal de esta naturaleza resulta sin paralelo en la historia marítima Antártica'. (Despacho R.T de Director del British Antarctic Survey) '']</ref>
[[Marambio Base]] was founded in 1969, currently the most important Argentine base on the Antarctica. In 1975 the [[Esperanza Base]] was built, and in 1979 the [[General Belgrano II]]. In 1978, the first Antarctic baby, [[Emilio Palma]], was born in the ''Fortín Sargento Cabral'' at the [[Esperanza Base]].
===IAA in the 21st Century=== [[Image:Q5ARAAlmiranteIrizar.jpg|thumb|right|''Almirante Irízar'' icebreaker.]]
In 2002, the Argentine Navy mounted an internal operation sending Icebreaker [[ARA Almirante Irízar (Q-5)|ARA ''Almirante Irizar'']] to rescue the trapped supply vessel ''[[Magdalena Oldendorff]]''. Even though Irízar failed to break the ''Oldendorff'' free, she managed to move it to a safe position and re-supply the ship with food, medicines and medical personnel until the ice melted and the ship could return to open sea.
In 2003, under the Decree Nº 207/2003 issued by the Executive Power of Argentina, the Instituto Antártico Argentino became a part of the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs, International Trade and Worship|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]]
On the 2009 summer campaign, the [[Argentine Air Force]] operated the [[Teniente Matienzo Base]] only with women for three months <ref>[http://www.lanacion.com.ar/nota.asp?nota_id=1086906 Una base antártica exclusiva para mujeres]</ref><ref>[http://defdigital.com.ar/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&catid=44%3Adefensa&id=226%3Aexperiencia-unica-mujeres-en-la-antartida&Itemid=112 Mujeres en la Antártida]</ref> although there was an emergency link available with the [[Bell 212]]s helicopters stationed at [[Marambio Base]]
On 2010 a [[Wind generators|Wind generator]] designed and built by Argentine government company [[CITEDEF]] was installed on Marambio Base <ref>[http://www.mindef.gov.ar/info.asp?Id=1425 DEFENSA INSTALÓ UN GENERADOR DE ENERGÍA EÓLICA EN LA ANTÁRTIDA] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20111101083658/http://www.mindef.gov.ar/info.asp?Id=1425 |date=2011-11-01 }}</ref>
On 2011, three heavy lift helicopters were deployed in the [[Base Marambio]]: two [[Mil Mi 17]] helicopters (bought in the same year), and the remaining [[Boeing CH-47 Chinook|Chinook]] from the [[Argentine Air Force]].
== See also == *[[Viviana Alder]]
==References== {{reflist}} *{{es icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20080117220618/http://www.cpel.uba.ar/filargenta/correo/anta0047.htm Argentine Antarctica History] *{{es icon}} [http://www.histarmar.com.ar/Armada%20Argentina/Buques1900a1970/BPolares/BPRompSMartin.htm ARA San Martin Icebreaker]
==External links== {{commons category|Antártida Argentina}} *{{en icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20110303004340/http://www.dna.gov.ar/INGLES/INDEX.HTM official site] *{{es icon}} [http://www.dna.gov.ar official site]

{{Infobox spaceflight | name = Intelsat V F-6 → Intelsat 506 | image = | image_caption = | mission_type = [[Communications satellite|Communication]] | operator = [[Intelsat]] | website = | COSPAR_ID = 1983-047A{{cite web|url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1983-047A|title=INTELSAT 5 F-6|publisher=National Space Science Data Center|accessdate=April 23, 2017}} | SATCAT = 14077 | mission_duration = 15 years | spacecraft_bus = [[Spacebus|Intelsat-V]] bus | manufacturer = [[Ford Aerospace]] | BOL_mass = {{convert|1012|kg|lb}}{{cite web|url=http://space.skyrocket.de/doc_sdat/intelsat-5.htm|title=Intelsat-5|publisher=Gunter's Space Page|accessdate=April 23, 2017}} | launch_mass = {{convert|1928.2|kg|lb}} | power = | launch_date = {{start-date|May 19, 1983, 22:26|timezone=yes}} UTC{{cite web|url=http://planet4589.org/space/log/launchlog.txt|title=Launch Log|first=Jonathan|last=McDowell|work=Jonathan's Space Page|accessdate=April 23, 2017}} | launch_rocket = [[Atlas-Centaur|Atlas SLV-3D Centaur-D1AR]] | launch_site = [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]] [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station Launch Complex 36|LC-36A]] | launch_contractor = | entered_service = | disposal_type = Decommissioned | deactivated = {{end-date|July, 1998}} | orbit_epoch = April 23, 2017{{cite web|url=https://www.n2yo.com/satellite/?s=14077|title=Intelsat 505|work=N2yo.com|accessdate=April 23, 2017}} | orbit_reference = [[Geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Geostationary orbit|Geostationary]] | orbit_periapsis = {{convert|35,946.6|km|mi|sp=us}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|36,269.0|km|mi|sp=us}} | orbit_inclination = 15.3 degrees | orbit_semimajor = {{convert|42478|km|mi|sp=us}} | orbit_period = 1,452.2 minutes | orbit_longitude = 64° W (current position) | apsis = gee | trans_band = 21 [[C band (IEEE)|C-band]]
4 {{Ku band}} | trans_frequency = | trans_capacity = | trans_coverage = | trans_TWTA = | trans_EIRP = | trans_HPBW = | programme = ''Intelsat V'' | previous_mission = [[Intelsat V F-5]] | next_mission = [[Intelsat V F-7]] }} '''Intelsat 506''', previously named '''Intelsat V F-6''', was a [[communications satellite]] operated by [[Intelsat]]. Launched in 1983, it was the sixth of fifteen [[Intelsat V]] satellites to be launched. The Intelsat V series was constructed by [[Ford Aerospace]], based on the [[Spacebus|Intelsat-V]] [[satellite bus]]. Intelsat V F-6 was part of an advanced series of satellites designed to provide greater telecommunications capacity for [[Intelsat]]'s global network. He also carried a '''Maritime Communications Services''' ('''MCS''') package for [[Inmarsat]]. The satellite was deactivated on July, 1998. The satellite was successfully launched into space on May 19, 1982, at 22:26 UTC, by means of an [[Atlas-Centaur|Atlas SLV-3D Centaur-D1AR]] vehicle from the [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station]], [[Florida]], [[United States]]. It had a launch mass of 1,928 kg.{{cite web|url=http://www.tbs-satellite.com/tse/online/sat_intelsat_506.html|title=INTELSAT 506|publisher=TSE|accessdate=April 23, 2017}} The Intelsat 506 was equipped with 4 [[Ku-band]] transponders more 21 [[C band (IEEE)|C-band]] [[transponder]]s for 12,000 audio circuits and 2 TV channels. ==References== {{reflist|2}} {{Portal|Spaceflight}} {{Intelsat}} {{Orbital launches in 1983}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1983]] [[Category:Intelsat satellites]] {{US-spacecraft-stub}}

page.title: Inter-American Institute for Global Change Research

revision.text:
{{advert|date=August 2018}} The '''Inter-American Institute for Global Change Research''', IAI, is an [[International organization|intergovernmental organization]] supported by 19 countries in the Americas, dedicated to pursuing the principles of scientific excellence, international cooperation, and the full and open exchange of scientific information to increase the understanding of [[global change]] phenomena and their [[Socioeconomics|socio-economic]] implications.
Recognizing the need to better understand the natural and social processes which drive large scale [[Climate change|environmental change]], the IAI encourages interactive exchanges between scientists and policy makers. The goal of the IAI is to augment the scientific capacity in the region and to provide information to policy makers in a useful and timely manner. Its primary objective is to encourage research beyond the scope of national programs, by advancing comparative and focused studies based on scientific issues important to the region as a whole.
==The IAI's Mission==
To develop the capacity of understanding the integrated impact of present and future global change on regional and continental environments in the Americas and to promote collaborative research and informed action at all levels.
==The IAI's Core values==
IAI pursues the principles of scientific excellence, international cooperation and full and open exchange of scientific information relevant to global environmental change.
==The IAI's Vision==
The IAI was envisaged as an intergovernmental instrument by which scientists and decision makers of countries throughout the Americas might jointly address the critical issues associated with global change in the region.
==Background==
As evidenced by the participation of most of the worlds leaders in [[United Nations|the United Nations]] Conference on Environment and Development ([[Earth Summit|UNCED]]) in [[Rio de Janeiro|Rio de Janeiro, Brazil]], June 1992, the phenomenon of global change is perceived as one of the most critical challenges facing the world today. Physical and socio-economic evidence of global change related phenomena such as [[ozone depletion]], loss of [[Biodiversity|biological diversity]] and changes in rainfall patterns and intensity, can be found in all areas of the world. Regardless of whether the particular phenomenon is natural or human-induced, its effects often cross geopolitical borders. Thus, many [[List of environmental issues|environmental issues]] must be addressed scientifically as global or regional problems, with steps towards mitigation or alleviation taken at a national level.
==History==
In response to the plea of a regional approach entity to address global change issues, sixteen nations<ref>Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Canada, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Mexico, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, United States, and Uruguay.</ref> in the Americas signed the '''Agreement establishing the Inter-American Institute for Global Change Research''' on May 13, 1992, in [[Montevideo|Montevideo, Uruguay]]. The treaty has been ratified by all 16 signatories and has been acceded to by three other American nations.<ref>Guatemala, Jamaica, and Venezuela.</ref> The agreement came into force on March 12, 1994, thus creating the IAI.<ref>[http://www.oas.org/juridico/english/sigs/c-19.html].</ref>
To accomplish IAI's mission and goals, in 1992 contributing scientists and science managers of the region crafted an initial Science Agenda. In 1997, in response to the evolving regional priorities, the IAI Scientific Advisory Committee revised the initial Science Agenda, re-arranged it and included new pressing issues in the current IAI Science Agenda.
Each member country participating in the IAI benefits from the enhancement of regional relationships, the establishment of new institutional arrangements, open exchange of scientific data, and information generated by the Institute's research programs, and the implementation of IAI Training and Education Programs.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gual Soler|first1=Marga|title=Intergovernmental Scientific Networks in Latin America: Supporting Broader Regional Relationships and Integration|journal=Science & Diplomacy|volume=3|issue=4|url=http://www.sciencediplomacy.org/article/2014/intergovernmental-scientific-networks-in-latin-america|author-link=Marga Gual Soler}}</ref>
The United States [[National Science Foundation]] hosted the IAI Secretariat from September 1994 until September 1996. Afterwards, the IAI became fully operational at the IAI Directorate located in the campus of the [[Instituto Nacional de Pesquisas Espaciais]] (INPE) in [[São José dos Campos]], Brazil.
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.iai.int iai.int]: official website

{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Kevin Greening | image = Kevin_Greening_2002.JPG | image_size = 176×203 | caption = | birth_name = Kevin Greening | birth_date = {{birth date|1962|12|30|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Kent]], England<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/comment/obituaries/article3115066.ece |title=Kevin Greening: Veteran disc jockey whose wit and sensitivity graced the airwaves of BBC Radio |date=1 January 2008 |publisher=The Times |accessdate=2 January 2008 | location=London}}</ref> | death_date = {{death date and age|2007|12|29|1962|12|30|df=y}} | death_place = [[Wandsworth]], [[south London]], England<ref name="arrest"/> | death_cause = Heart attack (due to a drug overdose) | resting_place = Herongate Wood Cemetery, Brentwood, Essex. | resting_place_coordinates = | residence = | nationality = British | other_names = | known_for = | education = [[St Catharine's College, Cambridge]] | occupation = [[Radio DJ]] | partner = Sean Griffin | relatives = | website = }} '''Kevin Greening''' (30 December 1962 – 29 December 2007<ref name="bbcnews">{{cite news |first=Kevin |last=Young |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/7165356.stm |title=Ex-BBC DJ Greening dies aged 44 |date=30 December 2007 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=31 December 2007}}</ref>) was a British radio presenter, who co-hosted ''[[The Radio 1 Breakfast Show]]'' on [[BBC Radio 1]] with [[Zoë Ball]] from 1997 to 1998.
==Early career== Kevin Greening grew up in [[Bristol]] where he worked voluntarily for the Bristol Hospital Broadcasting Service and was educated at [[Bristol Grammar School]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1574088/Kevin-Greening.html | work=The Daily Telegraph | location=London | title=Kevin Greening | date=31 December 2007 | accessdate=7 May 2010}}</ref> He later studied [[chemical engineering]] at [[St Catharine's College, Cambridge]], where he was station manager at [[Cambridge University Radio]]. His first job was as a [[Construction|construction worker]] on the [[Humber Bridge]]. He then trained as a studio manager and began his broadcasting career at the [[BBC World Service]]. After a brief spell as a Programme assistant at BBC Radio Solent, in 1989 Greening joined London's Local station [[BBC London 94.9|BBC GLR]] as a producer, before becoming a presenter of their Breakfast show in 1991.
In April 1993, Greening joined the newly launched [[Virgin Radio]], presenting a Friday and Saturday evening show and a Sunday morning show. After two months, he took over their weekday afternoon show, where he remained until he quit Virgin in December 1993.
==Radio 1== In January 1994, Greening joined [[BBC Radio 1]], presenting the Weekend Breakfast Show (Saturday and Sunday 7{{snd}}10{{nbsp}}am). In the summer of '94, Radio 1 agreed to cover the [[Gay Pride]] event for the first time and these reports into the general days' output were fronted by Greening; the success of these led to Radio 1 becoming a regular fixture at Gay Pride events. In May 1995 Greening was named in [[Gay Times]]' ''Top 200 Gay Men and Lesbians'' as an out gay DJ.<ref name="GT">{{Cite journal|journal=Gay Times|title=Top 200 Gay Men and Lesbians|page=28|date=May 1995|issue=200|first=Colin|last=Richardson|issn=0950-6101|postscript=<!--None-->}}</ref>
In November 1994, Greening took over the Weekend Lunchtime show (Saturday and Sunday noon to 2{{nbsp}}pm). Again he featured many of his comedy characters (usually voiced by [[Andrew McGibbon]]<ref name="Guardian obit">{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/obituaries/story/0,,2234311,00.html |title=Kevin Greening – Creative presenter who helped to salvage the Radio 1 breakfast show |date=3 January 2008 |publisher=Guardian |accessdate=22 January 2008 | location=London | first=Trevor | last=Dann}}</ref>) featured on Weekend Breakfast. October 1995 saw Greening move back to Weekend Breakfast where he would remain for another 16 months. Greening was given the Drivetime show in February 1997. Regular features on the show included the "Joke du Jour", "60 Second Cinema", and the "Evening Procession".
Early mornings seemed to play a big role during Greening's time at Radio 1, as he had presented Weekend Breakfast and had also been the main stand-in presenter for [[Steve Wright (DJ)|Steve Wright]], [[Chris Evans (British broadcaster)|Chris Evans]] and [[Mark Radcliffe (radio broadcaster)|Mark Radcliffe]] on the weekday breakfast show, but October 1997 saw Greening present ''[[The Radio 1 Breakfast Show]]'' alongside [[Zoë Ball]], where he would remain for 12 months.
Greening moved to a Sunday morning show from 6:30 to 10{{nbsp}}am in September 1998. At the time he was also presenting shows for [[BBC World Service]] and a TV show for digital station [[BBC Choice]]. It was during this period that Greening became the main stand-in presenter on the network, covering for many weekday presenters including [[Scott Mills]], [[Simon Mayo]] and [[Mark Radcliffe (radio broadcaster)|Mark Radcliffe]]. There was also a period when Greening took over the weekday lunchtime show whilst regular presenter [[Jo Whiley]] was away on [[Parental leave|maternity leave]]. He occasionally made light of his status as a stand-in presenter, giving an alternative [[E-mail address|email address]] as supply.dj@bbc.co.uk (his main address being kevin.greening@bbc.co.uk)
On Sunday 16 January 2000, Greening presented his final Radio 1 show. In the last half-hour he played some of the sketches from his time with the station.
==Radio 5 Live== Not long after he left Radio 1, in 2000 Greening moved to [[BBC Radio 5 Live]], where he was a stand-in presenter for various daytime slots.<ref>{{Cite book |first=Janet |last=Trewin |year=2003 |publisher=[[Elsevier]] |title=Presenting on TV and Radio: An Insider's Guide |isbn=0-240-51906-X |pages=116–117}}</ref>
In March 2001, whilst undertaking supply work at Five Live, he began co-presenting a Saturday Morning show on GLR's replacement, [[BBC London 94.9#BBC London Live .282000 - 2001.29|BBC London Live]], alongside [[Amanda Hussain]], the show went out from 8 to 11{{nbsp}}am on Saturday mornings and lasted until September the same year when the show was taken over by [[Danny Baker]].
==Commercial radio== From late 2001 into 2002, [[102.2 Jazz FM]] employed him for various slots, then in May 2002, he briefly joined London's [[Heart 106.2]] presenting their 2{{snd}}6{{nbsp}}pm weekend afternoon show.
In June 2002, he joined London's Rock station [[Xfm London|XFM]], sitting in for [[Christian O'Connell]] on the Breakfast Show. One month later, he took over the station's mid-morning slot from 10{{nbsp}}am to 1{{nbsp}}pm, where he remained until December 2003.
In January 2004, he was moved to the Station's ''Best of X'' show on Saturday evenings from 6 to 9{{nbsp}}pm.
After a stand-in stint on the [[BBC 6 Music]] Night Train programme, and in addition to his Saturday evening show on [[Xfm London|XFM]], in April 2004, he re-joined 102.2 Jazz FM to present a Sunday morning show from 10{{nbsp}}am to 2{{nbsp}}pm. Shortly after, he also took over from [[Clive Warren]] on Saturdays from 10{{nbsp}}am to 2{{nbsp}}pm.
On 7 June 2005, he took over the 10{{nbsp}}am{{snd}}3{{nbsp}}pm slot on 102.2 Jazz FM's replacement, [[102.2 Smooth FM]]. From 26 March 2007, he moved to a 1{{snd}}4{{nbsp}}pm weekday afternoon slot on the relaunched [[102.2 Smooth Radio]] where he built up a cult following. His "game with no name" quiz show, in which listeners had to suggest the most suitable song to play against a particular news item, was particularly popular.
He also presented Saturday afternoons from 2 to 5{{nbsp}}pm on the station.
==Personal life==
Greening was awarded a Fellowship by The [[Radio Academy]] in 2001,<ref>The Radio Academy [http://www.radioacademy.org/about/fellows/ "Fellows"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141024171034/http://www.radioacademy.org/about/fellows/ |date=24 October 2014 }}</ref>. He was the only non-executive ever to be so honoured in the academy's 25 years.<ref name="Guardian obit" />
Greening was openly gay<ref name="GT"/> and had a previous long-term relationship with Andy Lowe, whom he often referred to on air as his "lesbian life-partner" or "live-in chum". When their relationship came to an end in 2005, after a brief separation they continued to share their house in [[north London]].
At the time of his death Greening had been in a relationship with Sean Griffin for some time.<ref name="Guardian obit" />
==Death== On 30 December 2007, it was announced by Chris North, Greening's agent, that Greening had "died peacefully in his sleep" one day before his 45th birthday.<ref name="bbcnews"/> His boyfriend, Sean Griffin, was arrested the following day in connection with his death, and for possession of a [[Misuse of Drugs Act 1971#Penalties|Class A drug]],<ref name="arrest">{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7166439.stm |title=Man arrested after Greening death |date=1 January 2008 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=1 January 2008}}</ref> but charges in relation to Greening's death were not pursued by police.
On 3 January 2008, it was revealed following the [[Autopsy|post-mortem]] that Greening died of a heart attack after taking large quantities of [[cocaine]], [[Methylenedioxymethamphetamine|ecstasy]] and [[Gamma-Hydroxybutyric acid|GHB]].<ref name="Former radio DJ killed">{{cite web |url=http://www.nme.com/news/nme/33433 |title=Former Radio 1 DJ killed by 'sex and drugs binge' |publisher = [[NME]] |date=3 January 2007}}</ref> He had spent part of the night prior to his death at the Recon event<ref>Recon is a [[Fetish clothing|fetish wear]] on-line store http://shop.recon.com with an associated [[social network]] http://www.recon.com</ref> held at The Arches nightclub in [[Southwark]], London.
Greening was buried on 18 January 2008 in a [[Natural burial|woodland burial ground]] after a [[Secular humanism|secular humanist]] farewell ceremony in accordance with his wishes.
At the inquest into his death, a verdict of death by misadventure was recorded as a result of a self-induced drug overdose.<ref>[http://news.sky.com/skynews/article/0,,91248-1317928,00.html DJ Died After Gay Bondage Session] ''[[Sky News]]''</ref>
After his death an award was named after him at the [[Student Radio Association|Student Radio Association's]] annual Student Radio Awards. The Kevin Greening Award is dedicated to recognising unique on-air creativity, for which Greening was known.
==References== {{reflist}}

[[File:Inside view of Kohvik Moon, Tallinn, Estonia.jpg|thumb|Kohvik Moon]] [[File:Fillet of beef at restaurant Kohvik Moon, Tallinn, Estonia.jpg|thumb|Fillet of beef in red wine sauce, with potato pancakes and vegetables, one of the most famous dishes in Kohvik Moon]] '''Kohvik Moon''' is a [[restaurant]] in [[Tallinn]], [[Estonia]], located near the [[Viking Line]] harbour.
The restaurant focuses on simple food. Despite its small size and non-central location, it is so popular that since its opening in December 2010, the restaurant was almost full of customers every day for several months, and its owners often had to work almost round the clock.<ref>[http://www.hs.fi/ruoka/artikkeli/1+Kohvik+Moon+on+etsimisen+v%C3%A4%C3%A4rti/1135256961232 Kohvik Moon on etsimisen väärti]. ''[[Helsingin Sanomat]]'' 20 May 2010. Accessed on 2 August 2012.{{dead link|date=August 2016}}</ref> The restaurant was chosen as the best restaurant in Tallinn of the year in 2010.<ref>[http://www.e24.ee/264908/tallinna-parima-soogikoha-tiitli-noppis-uustulnuk-kohvik-moon/ "Tallinna parima söögikoha tiitli noppis uustulnuk kohvik Moon"] Postimees, 19 May 2010. Accessed on 7 March 2013. {{dead link|date=August 2016}}</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://www.kohvikmoon.ee Official site]

{{Infobox TV channel | name = MYtv | logosize = 200px | logofile = MyTV LOGO.jpg | logoalt = MYtv logo | slogan = Vir Ons Mense | launch = February 2009 | picture format = [[16:9]] ([[576i]], [[SDTV]]) | owner = [[Privately owned]] | country = [[South Africa]] |language = Afrikaans | broadcast area = [[Southern Africa]] | web = {{URL|http://www.mytv.co.za}} | sat serv 1 = [[StarSat]] | sat chan 1 = Channel 460 (SD) }} '''MYtv''' formally ASTV (Afrikaanse Satellietelevisie) is an Afrikaans Television Channel in South Africa which is privately owned.
The channel is based in Johannesburg South Africa and was first launched on [[Sentech]]'s Vivid platform in 2009 and then later launched on [[TopTV]] (now known as [[StarSat]]) October 2010.
ASTV started broadcasting on [[OVHD|OpenViewHD]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.astv.co.za/|title=MYtv|website=www.astv.co.za|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-09-08}}</ref> 15 October 2013. On 15 August 2016 ASTV announced that the channel will no longer be available on [[OVHD|OpenViewHD]] and the channel feed will be cutoff 14 October 2016 and they will still continue broadcasting on [[StarSat]].<ref>https://facebook.com/story.php?story_fbid=1158367187555949&id=191643584228319</ref>
From 1 March 2017 ASTV is known as MYtv.
==Content== MYtv broadcasts documentaries, educational, cooking, lifestyle and Afrikaans music videos content. The company producing the channel also produce TV adverts for advertisers and music videos for artists.
==See also== * [[List of South African television channels]] * [[Television in South Africa]] * [[TopTV]] * [[kykNET]] * [[StarSat]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.astv.co.za/ The official ASTV website] * [https://archive.is/20130105031239/http://vimeopro.com/astv/afrikaanse-satelliettelevisie/ ASTV vimeo page featuring full length episodes]
{{DEFAULTSORT:MYtv (South-Africa)}} [[Category:Television stations in South Africa]] [[Category:Afrikaans-language television]] [[Category:Media in Rustenburg]] [[Category:2010 establishments in South Africa]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 2009]]

The '''Maiestas Carolina''' was a [[legal code]] proposed by [[Charles IV, Holy Roman Emperor]] in 1350 to govern [[Bohemia]]. It received its name not before 1617.
Based on previous legal customs and the [[Liber Augustalis]] of 1231, the aim of the code was to increase royal power. Included among its provisions were sections granting the right to judge criminal cases solely to the king and others allowing the king greater control over functionaries in order to increase royal revenues. The code also contained sections regarding [[conservation movement|forest conservation]].
The Bohemian [[Diet (assembly)|Diet]] resented the loss of their own power and opposed the code. Charles withdrew the code in 1355, and it never came into effect.
== Bibliography ==
edited by [[František Palacký]], in: ''Archiv český'' 3 (1844), p. 65-180.
[[Category:Kingdom of Bohemia]]

{{BLP sources|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox film |name = Rustem's records with drawing |image = |caption = |director = [[Ardak Amirkulov]] |producer = |writer = [[Erzhan Rustembekov]]
[[Nariman Turebayev]] |starring = [[Erzhan Rustembekov]]
[[Aruzhan Sayin]]
[[Asel Shaimukhambetova]] |music = [[Kuat Shildebayev]] |cinematography = [[Renat Kusayev]]
[[Aleksandr Rubanov]] |editing = |distributor = [[Ardfilm]] |released = 1998 |runtime = 79 minutes |country = [[Kazakhstan]] |language = [[Russian language|Russian]] |budget = |gross = }} '''''Rustem's records with drawing''''' ({{lang-ru|Записи Рустема с картинками}}) is a 1998 [[Kazakhstan|Kazakh]] [[teen]] [[city ballad]] [[film]] ==Plot== Action of the picture consisting of four short stories happens in [[Almaty]] and covers three days between summer and fall of 1997 — from August 31 to September 2. Declared as records of the main character with drawings, it doesn't apply for serious research of the teenage environment — it more likely a look from within for a while which as if stopped at the birth of heroes in 1979. Eighteen-year-old Rustem, unlike the business little sister Madina, is lazy and inert, he looks at the world cold eyes, having hidden behind the indifferent relation to people around. The strange girl Miko shy tries to destroy Rustem's rest by fragile feeling of the first love. Almost all actors, screenwriters (second-year students of masterful direction of game cinema of Ardak Amirkulov), artists, operators — graduates or students of [[Kazakh National Academy of Arts]]. In the movie scenes from the performance "[[The Brothers Karamazov]]" are used. Amirkulov enters the movie in a cinema context, having remembered not only Nugmanov film "[[The Needle (1988 film)|The Needle]]", but also Daneliya film "[[Walking the Streets of Moscow]]" and Ioseliani film "There lived a song thrush", beating through motive of the last fortieth anniversary — the city aimless wanderings of the hero behaving to finding, but coinciding often with finding of death. ==Cast== *Rustem as Erzhan Rustembekov *Madina as Aruzhan Sayin *Miko as Asel Shaimukhambetova *Talgat Zhanybekov *Gaziz Tleulin *Yerbolat Ospankulov *Bakytzhamal Kupiyalova *Sergei Makienko *Zhayik Syzdykov *Yelena Trenina *Farida Zhantelova *Akmaral Rasylkhanova *Gizat Sultanov *Oleg Akhmetov ==External links== * [http://km.ru/kino/encyclopedia/1997-zapisi-rustema-s-kartinkami] {{ru icon}} [[Category:1998 films]] [[Category:Kazakhstani films]] [[Category:Russian-language films]] [[Category:Films set in Kazakhstan]] {{Kazakhstan-film-stub}}

{{refimprove|date=December 2009}} The '''Satellite Home Viewer Act of 1988''' comprises a set of regulations which govern the transmissions of [[television station]]s in the United States, specifically imposing the restriction of [[satellite]] carrier transmissions of a [[Television network|network station]]'s transmissions only to subscribers who cannot receive these broadcasts via [[Antenna (radio)|antenna]] and have not subscribed to a [[cable television|cable system]] providing these broadcasts, and which also concern regularizing satellite carriers' submission of lists of subscribers to networks, the coordination of broadcasting fees with territorial coverage of transmissions, and the distribution of fees to [[copyright]] owners of works included in transmissions.<ref>http://www.wchstv.com/satellitefulltext.shtml</ref>
== See also == * [[Must-carry]] * [[Significantly viewed]]
==References== <references/>
http://transition.fcc.gov/mb/shva/
[[Category:Broadcast law]] [[Category:Television terminology]] [[Category:United States federal communications legislation]] [[Category:Cable television in the United States]] [[Category:Satellite television]]

The group consists of vocalist Cristina Caramarcu, guitarist Alexandru Cismaru, keyboardist Alexandru Matei, bassist Alin Neagoe, and drummer Adi Tetrade. They represented [[Romania in the Eurovision Song Contest 2018|Romania]] in the [[Eurovision Song Contest 2018]] in [[Lisbon]], [[Portugal]], with the song "[[Goodbye (The Humans song)|Goodbye]]".{{cite web|url=https://eurovoix.com/2018/02/25/romania-humans-eurovision-2018/|title=Romania: The Humans to Eurovision 2018|date=25 February 2018|publisher=Eurovoix|last=Herbert|first=Emily}}{{cite web|url=http://esctoday.com/160152/romania-humans-win-selectia-nationala-2018-and-are-off-to-lisbon/|title=Romania: The Humans win Selecția Națională 2018 and are off to Lisbon!|last=Agadellis|first=Stratos|date=25 February 2018|publisher=ESCToday}}{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/pg/TheHumansSounds/about/?ref=page_internal|accessdate=25 February 2018|publisher=The Humans|title=About}} ==Discography== ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! scope="col" style="width:12em;"| Title ! scope="col" style="width:1em;"| Year ! scope="col" style="width:10em;"| Album |- !scope="row"| "Îndură inima" | 2017 | rowspan="3" {{n/a|Non-album
singles}} |- ! scope="row"| "[[Goodbye (The Humans song)|Goodbye]]" | rowspan="2"|2018 |- ! scope="row"| "Binele meu" |- |} ==Band members== *Cristina Caramarcu-Lead vocals *Alexandru Cismaru-Lead guitar,backing vocals *Alexandru Matei-Keyboard,backing vocals *Alin Neagoe-bass,backing vocals *Adrian Tanase-Guitar,vocals *Pedro Adi Tetrade-Drums,percussion Supporting/additional members: *Corina Matei-Cello,violin,backing vocals ==References== {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | before=[[Ilinca Băcilă|Ilinca]] & [[Alex Florea]]

page.title: Zone of Peace, Freedom and Neutrality

revision.comment: Bot: Migrating interwiki links, now provided by [[d:|Wikidata]] on [[d:q136335]]
revision.text:
The '''Zone of Peace, Freedom and Neutrality (ZOPFAN)''' is a declaration signed by the Foreign Ministers of the [[ASEAN]] member states ([[Indonesia]], [[Malaysia]], the [[Philippines]], [[Singapore]] and [[Thailand]]) on 1971 in [[Kuala Lumpur]], Malaysia.
In the declaration, the parties publicly stated their intent to keep [[South East Asia]] "free from any form or manner of interference by outside Powers" and "broaden the areas of cooperation."
==External links== *[http://www.icnl.org/research/library/files/Transnational/zone.pdf Text of the declaration]
{{asia-law-stub}} [[Category:Association of Southeast Asian Nations laws]]
